title: Romans Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:1, who ought to bear the infirmities of the weak?
questions.correctAnswer: We that are strong
questions.explanation: Romans 15:1 states that 'We then that are strong ought to bear the infirmities of the weak, and not to please ourselves.'

questions.question: What does Romans 15:2 encourage us to do for our neighbour?
options: Please him for his good to edification
questions.correctAnswer: Please him for his good to edification
questions.explanation: Romans 15:2 says, 'Let every one of us please his neighbour for his good to edification.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 15:3 says that Christ pleased himself.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 15:3 clearly states, 'For even Christ pleased not himself; but, as it is written, The reproaches of them that reproached thee fell on me.'

questions.question: According to Romans 15:4, why were the things written aforetime written?
options: For our learning, patience, and hope
questions.correctAnswer: For our learning, patience, and hope
questions.explanation: Romans 15:4 explains that 'whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope.'

questions.question: Who does Romans 15:5 say is the God of patience and consolation?
questions.correctAnswer: God according to Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Romans 15:5 states, 'Now the God of patience and consolation grant you to be likeminded one toward another according to Christ Jesus.'

questions.question: Romans 15:6 encourages believers to glorify God with what?
questions.correctAnswer: One mind and one mouth
questions.explanation: Romans 15:6 says, 'That ye may with one mind and one mouth glorify God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 15:7 instructs us to receive one another as Christ received us.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 15:7 states, 'Wherefore receive ye one another, as Christ also received us to the glory of God.'

questions.question: What role did Jesus Christ serve according to Romans 15:8?
options: Minister of the circumcision to confirm the promises
questions.correctAnswer: Minister of the circumcision to confirm the promises
questions.explanation: Romans 15:8 says, 'Now I say that Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers.'

questions.question: According to Romans 15:9, why might the Gentiles glorify God?
questions.correctAnswer: For his mercy
questions.explanation: Romans 15:9 explains that the Gentiles might glorify God 'for his mercy; as it is written, For this cause I will confess to thee among the Gentiles, and sing unto thy name.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 15:13: 'Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in ______, that ye may abound in hope...'
questions.correctAnswer: believing
questions.explanation: Romans 15:13 states, 'Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost.'

questions.question: Romans 15:15 states Paul wrote boldly to the brethren because of what?
options: The grace given to him of God
questions.correctAnswer: The grace given to him of God
questions.explanation: Romans 15:15 says, 'Nevertheless, brethren, I have written the more boldly unto you in some sort, as putting you in mind, because of the grace that is given to me of God.'

questions.question: True or False: Romans 15:18 says Paul will speak of things Christ has not wrought by him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 15:18 states, 'For I will not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ hath not wrought by me.'

questions.question: In Romans 15:19, by what means did Paul make the Gentiles obedient?
options: By mighty signs and wonders through the Spirit of God
questions.correctAnswer: By mighty signs and wonders through the Spirit of God
questions.explanation: Romans 15:19 says Paul made the Gentiles obedient 'through mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God.'

questions.question: According to Romans 15:20, where did Paul avoid preaching the gospel?
questions.correctAnswer: Where Christ was already named
questions.explanation: Romans 15:20 says, 'I have strived to preach the gospel, not where Christ was named, lest I should build upon another man's foundation.'

questions.question: Who made a contribution for the poor saints at Jerusalem according to Romans 15:26?
questions.correctAnswer: Those of Macedonia and Achaia
questions.explanation: Romans 15:26 states, 'For it hath pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the poor saints which are at Jerusalem.'

medium.title: Romans Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Romans 15:1-2 teach us to live in community with those who are weaker in faith?
options: By bearing their infirmities and pleasing our neighbors for their good
By avoiding interactions to prevent conflict
By demanding everyone conform to our standards
By focusing only on pleasing ourselves
questions.correctAnswer: By bearing their infirmities and pleasing our neighbors for their good
questions.explanation: Romans 15:1-2 instructs the strong to bear the weaknesses of the weak and to please neighbors for their edification, encouraging humility and care within the community.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with selfishness. According to Romans 15:3, what example can you share to encourage selflessness?
options: Christ did not please Himself but bore reproaches for others
Paul demanded others conform to his teachings
Believers should seek personal comfort first
questions.correctAnswer: Christ did not please Himself but bore reproaches for others
questions.explanation: Romans 15:3 highlights Christ’s example of not pleasing Himself but taking on reproaches, showing believers the model for selfless living.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:4, how can the scriptures help us in trials?
options: By providing patience, comfort, and hope
By giving us immediate answers to all questions
questions.correctAnswer: By providing patience, comfort, and hope
questions.explanation: Romans 15:4 teaches that scriptures were written for our learning so we might have patience, comfort, and hope during trials.

questions.question: What does Romans 15:5-6 teach about unity among believers?
options: God grants us patience to be likeminded and glorify Him with one mind and mouth
Unity is not important for glorifying God
Believers should compete to show superiority
Unity is only for certain gifted individuals
questions.correctAnswer: God grants us patience to be likeminded and glorify Him with one mind and mouth
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 emphasize that God grants patience and consolation so believers can be united in mind and speech to glorify God.

questions.question: How does Romans 15:7 encourage us to treat fellow believers?
options: Receive one another just as Christ received us
Focus only on personal spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Receive one another just as Christ received us
questions.explanation: Romans 15:7 instructs believers to accept one another as Christ accepted us, promoting love and unity.

questions.question: What role did Jesus Christ fulfill according to Romans 15:8?
options: Minister of the circumcision to confirm God's promises
Only a teacher with no special role
A prophet sent only to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Minister of the circumcision to confirm God's promises
questions.explanation: Romans 15:8 states Jesus was minister to the circumcision (Jewish people) to confirm promises made to the fathers.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:9-12, what is the significance of Gentiles in God's plan?
options: Gentiles glorify God for His mercy and trust in the root of Jesse
Gentiles must adopt Jewish customs exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles glorify God for His mercy and trust in the root of Jesse
questions.explanation: Verses 9-12 show Gentiles are included to glorify God for His mercy and trust in the Messiah (root of Jesse).

questions.question: What does Romans 15:13 teach about the source of joy and peace in believing?
options: The God of hope fills believers through the power of the Holy Ghost
We must achieve joy and peace through self-effort
Joy and peace come from worldly success
Believers cannot have peace in this life
questions.correctAnswer: The God of hope fills believers through the power of the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 15:13 explains that God, the source of hope, fills believers with joy and peace through the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: Based on Romans 15:14, how should mature believers help one another?
options: By admonishing one another with knowledge and goodness
questions.correctAnswer: By admonishing one another with knowledge and goodness
questions.explanation: Romans 15:14 affirms mature believers are full of goodness and knowledge, able to admonish and encourage one another.

questions.question: Paul writes boldly in Romans 15:15-16 because of what reason?
options: Because of the grace given to him by God to minister to the Gentiles
Because he wanted to show superiority
Because he was angry with the Romans
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the grace given to him by God to minister to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Paul boldly writes as a reminder due to the grace God gave him to be a minister to the Gentiles (Romans 15:15-16).

questions.question: What means did Paul use to preach the gospel effectively according to Romans 15:18-19?
options: Words, deeds, and mighty signs by the power of the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Words, deeds, and mighty signs by the power of the Spirit
questions.explanation: Romans 15:18-19 describes Paul’s ministry involving words, deeds, and powerful signs by the Spirit to make Gentiles obedient.

questions.question: Why did Paul strive to preach the gospel in new regions according to Romans 15:20-21?
options: To avoid building on another man’s foundation and reach those who had not heard
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid building on another man’s foundation and reach those who had not heard
questions.explanation: Romans 15:20-21 states Paul preached where Christ was not named to reach unreached people and not build on others’ work.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 15:23-24, Paul desired to visit the Roman believers on his way to Spain if he had the opportunity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 15:23-24 shows Paul hoped to visit the Roman believers during his journey to Spain if circumstances allowed.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 15:26-27 teaches that Gentile believers owe no responsibility to support Jewish saints.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Romans 15:26-27 teaches that Gentiles, having shared in spiritual blessings, have a duty to support Jewish saints materially.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Romans 15:30 encourages believers to strive together with Paul in ________ for his ministry.
questions.correctAnswer: prayers
questions.explanation: Romans 15:30 urges believers to join Paul in prayer for his deliverance and successful ministry.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:1, what is the responsibility of the strong towards the weak?
options: Bear the infirmities of the weak and not please themselves
Ignore the weak to maintain personal strength
Teach the weak strictly without compassion
questions.correctAnswer: Bear the infirmities of the weak and not please themselves
questions.explanation: Romans 15:1 instructs that those who are strong ought to bear the infirmities of the weak and not to please themselves, highlighting a theme of mutual care and humility.

questions.question: What Old Testament figure is quoted in Romans 15:3 to illustrate Christ's attitude of not pleasing Himself?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Romans 15:3 quotes Psalm 69:9, attributed to David, showing Christ bearing reproaches for God's sake, which connects Christ’s suffering to David’s prophetic experiences.

questions.question: Romans 15:4 emphasizes the purpose of scriptures written 'aforetime.' What is this purpose?
options: For our learning, patience, comfort, and hope
To serve as historical records only
questions.correctAnswer: For our learning, patience, comfort, and hope
questions.explanation: Romans 15:4 teaches that scriptures were written for our learning so that through patience and comfort of the scriptures we might have hope, linking Old Testament teaching to Christian endurance.

questions.question: The phrase 'God of patience and consolation' in Romans 15:5 is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Epithets
questions.explanation: Romans 15:5 uses epithets, descriptive phrases highlighting God's attributes of patience and consolation, to encourage unity among believers.

questions.question: In Romans 15:7, Paul commands believers to receive one another as Christ received us. This command reflects which Old Testament theme?
questions.correctAnswer: Hospitality to strangers
questions.explanation: Romans 15:7’s call to receive one another echoes the Old Testament theme of hospitality, a cultural and religious value emphasizing acceptance and love.

questions.question: Romans 15:8 describes Jesus Christ as a minister of the circumcision. What does this role signify in the context of God's promises?
options: Confirming the promises made to the Jewish fathers
Rejecting the law given to Moses
Establishing a new religion separate from Judaism
questions.correctAnswer: Confirming the promises made to the Jewish fathers
questions.explanation: Romans 15:8 shows Christ ministering to the circumcision to confirm the promises made to the Jewish patriarchs, emphasizing continuity between the Old and New Covenants.

questions.question: What is the significance of the multiple Old Testament quotations in Romans 15:9-12?
options: They demonstrate fulfillment of prophecy in Gentile inclusion
They establish the supremacy of the Mosaic Law
They warn against Gentile worship practices
questions.correctAnswer: They demonstrate fulfillment of prophecy in Gentile inclusion
questions.explanation: Romans 15:9-12 uses Old Testament quotations (Psalms, Isaiah) to show that Gentiles glorifying God fulfills prophetic promises, highlighting the expansion of God's covenantal blessings.

questions.question: The 'root of Jesse' mentioned in Romans 15:12 is a typological reference to whom?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Romans 15:12 refers to Isaiah’s prophecy about the 'root of Jesse,' a messianic title pointing to Jesus as descendant of Jesse (David's father), who reigns over the Gentiles.

questions.question: In Romans 15:13, the 'God of hope' is said to fill believers with joy and peace through what means?
options: The power of the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: The power of the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 15:13 attributes joy and peace in believing to the power of the Holy Spirit, emphasizing spiritual empowerment for hope.

questions.question: Paul's ministry to the Gentiles, as described in Romans 15:16, is portrayed as what kind of offering?
options: Acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Ghost
Temporary until the temple is rebuilt
questions.correctAnswer: Acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Romans 15:16 describes Paul’s ministry as an offering of the Gentiles, made acceptable and sanctified through the Holy Spirit, symbolizing a new spiritual priesthood.

questions.question: Romans 15:18-19 discusses Paul’s work among the Gentiles. What unique method does Paul emphasize in making the Gentiles obedient?
options: By word and deed through mighty signs and wonders
By strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: By word and deed through mighty signs and wonders
questions.explanation: Romans 15:18-19 highlights that Paul’s ministry was empowered by signs and wonders through the Spirit, combining preaching with miraculous validation.

questions.question: What is the strategic reason Paul gives in Romans 15:20 for preaching the gospel only where Christ was not named?
options: To avoid building on another man's foundation
To prevent conflict with Jewish authorities
To maintain exclusivity of his message
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid building on another man's foundation
questions.explanation: Romans 15:20 shows Paul’s intention to spread the gospel in new regions to establish fresh foundations rather than preaching where others had already ministered.

questions.question: Romans 15:25-26 describe Paul's upcoming journey to Jerusalem. What is the main purpose of this trip?
options: To minister to the saints and deliver contributions from Macedonia and Achaia
To seek approval from the Sanhedrin
To begin a mission in Asia Minor
questions.correctAnswer: To minister to the saints and deliver contributions from Macedonia and Achaia
questions.explanation: Romans 15:25-26 explain Paul’s mission to Jerusalem involves ministering to the saints and carrying a financial contribution from the Gentile churches for the poor believers there.

questions.question: In Romans 15:27, Paul explains the Gentiles’ obligation to the Jewish believers based on what principle?
options: Because Gentiles have shared in their spiritual blessings, they owe support in material things
Because the Law demands strict tithes
Because the Gentiles must convert to Judaism
questions.correctAnswer: Because Gentiles have shared in their spiritual blessings, they owe support in material things
questions.explanation: Romans 15:27 teaches a principle of reciprocal grace: Gentiles have benefited spiritually from Israel and thus have a duty to help them materially.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 15:30-31, Paul requests believers to pray for his deliverance from unbelievers in Judaea and that his ministry to Jerusalem be accepted.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Romans 15:30-31 records Paul's appeal for prayer for protection from unbelievers in Judaea and for acceptance of his service to the Jerusalem saints.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:1, what is the primary responsibility of the strong towards the weak?
options: To bear the infirmities of the weak and not to please themselves
To judge the weak for their faults
To separate themselves from the weak
questions.correctAnswer: To bear the infirmities of the weak and not to please themselves
questions.explanation: Romans 15:1 teaches that those who are strong have a duty to bear the weaknesses of others without seeking self-pleasure. This aligns with Christ's example of humility (Philippians 2:3-4), the call to love one another (John 13:34), and the bearing of burdens in Galatians 6:2, emphasizing selflessness and care for others.

questions.question: What does Romans 15:4 say is the purpose of the things written aforetime?
options: For our learning, that through patience and comfort of the scriptures we might have hope
To provide legalistic rules for salvation
To reveal mysteries only to the elders
questions.correctAnswer: For our learning, that through patience and comfort of the scriptures we might have hope
questions.explanation: Romans 15:4 explains that the Scriptures were written for instruction to cultivate patience, encouragement, and hope. This is consistent with 2 Timothy 3:16-17 on Scripture's usefulness for teaching and encouragement, Psalm 119:105 about Scripture as light for the path, and Hebrews 11 which exemplifies hope through faith.

questions.question: In Romans 15:5-6, what is the desired result when believers are likeminded according to Christ Jesus?
options: That they may with one mind and one mouth glorify God the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
That they may impose their will on others
That they may compete for spiritual gifts
That they may establish a new law
questions.correctAnswer: That they may with one mind and one mouth glorify God the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes unity in mind and speech to glorify God corporately, reflecting the biblical theme of unity in the body of Christ (Ephesians 4:3-6), the priestly call to offer unified praise (Psalm 95:1-2), and Jesus' high priestly prayer for unity in John 17:20-23.

questions.question: Who does Romans 15:7 instruct believers to receive as Christ received them?
options: Those who agree with their doctrine
questions.correctAnswer: One another
questions.explanation: Romans 15:7 calls Christians to mutual acceptance, mirroring Christ's unconditional reception of believers. This principle is found in Ephesians 4:2, Colossians 3:13, and John 13:34-35, highlighting love and acceptance as marks of Christian community.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:8, what role did Jesus Christ fulfill with regard to the circumcision?
options: Minister of the circumcision to confirm the promises made unto the fathers
One who abolished the law for the circumcision
A servant only to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Minister of the circumcision to confirm the promises made unto the fathers
questions.explanation: This verse reveals Christ’s mission to the Jewish people to affirm God's promises to the patriarchs, consistent with Luke 1:54-55, Hebrews 6:13-17, and Matthew 5:17 where Jesus fulfills the Law and the Prophets, confirming the covenantal promises.

questions.question: Romans 15:9 states that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy. Which Old Testament practice is cited to support this?
options: Confessing and singing to God's name among the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Confessing and singing to God's name among the Gentiles
questions.explanation: The verse quotes Psalm 18:49, showing that Gentiles praising God is a fulfillment of Scripture. This aligns with Isaiah 56:6-7, Psalm 117:1, and Zephaniah 3:9 where Gentiles joining in worship is anticipated as part of God's redemptive plan.

questions.question: Which prophecy about the Messiah and the Gentiles is quoted in Romans 15:12?
options: There shall be a root of Jesse who will reign over the Gentiles, and in him shall the Gentiles trust
The Messiah will come only for Israel and exclude Gentiles
The Messiah will establish a purely Jewish kingdom
The Gentiles will reject the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: There shall be a root of Jesse who will reign over the Gentiles, and in him shall the Gentiles trust
questions.explanation: Romans 15:12 cites Isaiah 11:1-10, emphasizing the Messiah’s universal reign and the inclusion of Gentiles in salvation, consistent with Acts 10:34-35, Psalm 22:27, and Revelation 5:9 where Gentile inclusion in God's kingdom is affirmed.

questions.question: What does Romans 15:13 describe as the source of joy, peace, and hope for believers?
options: The God of hope through the power of the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: The God of hope through the power of the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: This verse highlights that joy, peace, and hope come from God by the Holy Spirit's power, which aligns with Galatians 5:22-23 on the fruit of the Spirit, John 14:16-17 on the Spirit as a helper, and Romans 5:5 regarding hope that does not disappoint.

questions.question: In Romans 15:16, Paul describes his ministry to the Gentiles. What is the purpose of his service?
options: Ministering the gospel so that the offering of the Gentiles might be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Ghost
Converting the Gentiles to Jewish customs
questions.correctAnswer: Ministering the gospel so that the offering of the Gentiles might be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Paul’s ministry aims to present Gentiles as a sanctified offering to God through the gospel, echoing Leviticus 1:3-4 on offerings, Ephesians 5:25-27 on sanctification, and Hebrews 13:15-16 about spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:18-19, by what means did Paul make the Gentiles obedient?
options: By word and deed through mighty signs and wonders by the power of the Spirit of God
questions.correctAnswer: By word and deed through mighty signs and wonders by the power of the Spirit of God
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes the Spirit-empowered ministry involving both proclamation and miraculous signs, consistent with Acts 2:43, 1 Corinthians 2:4, Mark 16:20, and Hebrews 2:4 where signs confirm the gospel message.

questions.question: What reason does Paul give in Romans 15:20 for preaching the gospel where Christ was not yet named?
options: So he would not build upon another man's foundation
To avoid preaching to the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: So he would not build upon another man's foundation
questions.explanation: Paul sought to pioneer new areas for the gospel rather than overlap with others’ ministries, reflecting 1 Corinthians 3:10-15 about God’s foundation, Acts 16:6-10 on guidance by the Spirit to new fields, and 2 Timothy 4:5 about fulfilling ministry wisely.

questions.question: In Romans 15:21, what Old Testament principle does Paul cite to explain his mission strategy?
options: To whom he was not spoken of, they shall see; and they that have not heard shall understand
To only preach to those who are already faithful
To keep the gospel secret from Gentiles
To avoid preaching in cities with synagogues
questions.correctAnswer: To whom he was not spoken of, they shall see; and they that have not heard shall understand
questions.explanation: Paul quotes Isaiah 52:15 to express the prophetic mandate that the gospel would reach those previously unreached, consistent with Matthew 28:19, Acts 1:8 on global mission, and Psalm 67:2 about all nations praising God.

questions.question: What is Paul's stated reason in Romans 15:22-23 for his delay in visiting the Roman believers?
options: He has been much hindered from coming to them
He is unwilling to visit them
He is waiting for financial support
questions.correctAnswer: He has been much hindered from coming to them
questions.explanation: Paul acknowledges practical hindrances to travel, reflecting the reality of apostolic ministry challenges as seen in Acts 16:6-10 and 2 Corinthians 11:23-28, showing perseverance despite obstacles.

questions.question: What future travel plan does Paul reveal in Romans 15:24 and 28?
options: To journey to Spain and plans to visit the Romans on the way
questions.correctAnswer: To journey to Spain and plans to visit the Romans on the way
questions.explanation: Paul expresses his long-held desire to visit Spain and intends to stop in Rome en route, demonstrating the early church's expanding mission (Acts 19:21), and the apostolic commitment to spread the gospel westward.

questions.question: According to Romans 15:26-27, why did Macedonia and Achaia make a contribution for the poor saints in Jerusalem?
options: Because they were indebted to the Jerusalem saints, having shared in their spiritual blessings
Because Jerusalem forced them to give
Because they wanted to establish a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Because they were indebted to the Jerusalem saints, having shared in their spiritual blessings
questions.explanation: Paul explains the reciprocal responsibility among believers, reflecting principles in Galatians 6:6, 2 Corinthians 8, and Acts 11:29-30 about sharing material resources as an expression of unity and gratitude.
